description: From Middle English turnen, from Old English turnian, tyrnan (“to turn, rotate, revolve”) and Old French torner (“to turn”), both from Latin tornāre (“to round off, turn in a lathe”), from tornus (“lathe”), from Ancient Greek τόρνος (tórnos, “turning-lathe: a tool used for making circles”), from Proto-Indo-European *terh₁- (“to rub, rub by turning, turn, twist, bore”). Cognate with Old English þrāwan (“to turn, twist, wind”). Displaced native Old English wendan.

verbs.description: turn (third-person singular simple present turns, present participle turning, simple past and past participle turned or (obsolete) turnt)

definitionGroups.group: To make a non-linear physical movement.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) Of a body, person, etc, to move around an axis through itself.
examples: the Earth turns;  turn on the spot

entries.meaning: (transitive) To change the direction or orientation of, especially by rotation.
examples: Turn the knob clockwise.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To change one's direction of travel.
examples: She turned right at the corner.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To shape (something) symmetrically by rotating it against a stationary cutting tool, as on a lathe.
examples: She turned the table legs with care and precision.

entries.meaning: (by extension) To give form to; to shape or mould; to adapt.
(transitive) To position (something) by folding it, or using its folds.
examples: turn the bed covers;  turn the pages

entries.meaning: (transitive, figuratively) To navigate through a book or other printed material.
examples: turn to page twenty;  turn through the book

entries.meaning: (transitive, cricket) Of a bowler, to make (the ball) move sideways off the pitch when it bounces.
(intransitive, cricket) Of a ball, to move sideways off the pitch when it bounces.
(copulative) To become (begin to be).
examples: Synonyms: become, get
The leaves turn brown in autumn. When I asked him for the money, he turned nasty.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To change the color of the leaves in the autumn.
examples: The hillside behind our house isn't generally much to look at, but once all the trees turn it's gorgeous.

entries.meaning: To change fundamentally; to metamorphose.
examples: Midas made everything turn to gold.  He turned into a monster every full moon.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To sour or spoil; to go bad.
examples: This milk has turned; it smells awful.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make acid or sour; to ferment; to curdle.
examples: to turn cider or wine

entries.meaning: (transitive, fantasy) To change (a person) into a vampire, werewolf, zombie, etc.
examples: How long ago was he turned?

entries.meaning: (intransitive, fantasy) To transform into a vampire, werewolf, zombie, etc.
examples: Bruce Banner turns when he is angry; he becomes the Hulk, an incredibly powerful green monster.

entries.meaning: To reach a certain age.
examples: Charlie turns six on September 29.

entries.meaning: To hinge; to depend.
examples: The decision turns on a single fact.

entries.meaning: To rebel; to go against something formerly tolerated.
examples: The prisoners turned on the warden.

entries.meaning: To change personal condition.
examples: The sight turned my stomach.

entries.meaning: (professional wrestling) To change personalities, such as from being a face (good guy) to heel (bad guy) or vice versa.
To become giddy; said of the head or brain.
To sicken; to nauseate.
examples: The sight turned my stomach.

entries.meaning: To be nauseated; said of the stomach.
(obsolete, reflexive) To change one's course of action; to take a new approach.
(transitive, usually with over) To complete.
examples: They say they can turn the parts in two days.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make (money); turn a profit.
examples: We turned a pretty penny with that little scheme.

entries.meaning: (transitive, soccer) Of a player, to go past an opposition player with the ball in one's control.
To undergo the process of turning on a lathe.
examples: Ivory turns well.

entries.meaning: (obstetrics) To bring down the feet of a child in the womb, in order to facilitate delivery.
(printing, dated) To invert a type of the same thickness, as a temporary substitute for any sort which is exhausted.
(archaic) To translate.
examples: to turn the Iliad

entries.meaning: (transitive, role-playing games) To magically or divinely attack undead.

description: Partly from Anglo-Norman *torn, from Latin turnus, from Ancient Greek τόρνος (tórnos), and partly an action noun from the verb turn.

entries.meaning: A change of direction or orientation.
examples: Give the handle a turn, then pull it.

definitionGroups.group: A movement of an object about its own axis in one direction that continues until the object returns to its initial orientation.

entries.meaning: (geometry) A unit of plane angle measurement based on this movement.
A walk to and fro.
examples: Let's take a turn in the garden.
Synonym: promenade

entries.meaning: A chance to use (something) shared in sequence with others.
examples: They took turns playing with the new toy.

entries.meaning: A spell of work, especially the time allotted to a person in a rota or schedule.
examples: I cooked tonight, so it's your turn to do the dishes.

entries.meaning: One's chance to make a move in a game having two or more players.
A figure in music, often denoted ~, consisting of the note above the one indicated, the note itself, the note below the one indicated, and the note itself again.
The time required to complete a project.
examples: They quote a three-day turn on parts like those.
Synonym: turnaround

entries.meaning: A fit or a period of giddiness.
examples: I've had a funny turn.

entries.meaning: A change in temperament or circumstance.
examples: She took a turn for the worse.

entries.meaning: (cricket) A sideways movement of the ball when it bounces (caused by rotation in flight).
(poker) The fourth communal card in Texas hold 'em.
(poker, obsolete) The flop (the first three community cards) in Texas hold 'em.
A deed done to another; an act of kindness or malice.
examples: One good turn deserves another.
I felt that the man was of a vindictive nature, and would do me an evil turn if he found the opportunity […].

entries.meaning: A single loop of a coil.
(rope) A pass behind or through an object.
Character; personality; nature.
(soccer) An instance of going past an opposition player with the ball in one's control.
(circus, theater, especially physical comedy) A short skit, act, or routine.
examples: Between the pieces were individual turns, comic songs and dances.

entries.meaning: (printing, dated) A type turned upside down to serve for another character that is not available.
(UK, finance, historical) The profit made by a stockjobber, being the difference between the buying and selling prices.
examples: There are usually at least two jobbers who specialise in the leading stocks, and this acts to keep the jobber's turn to a reasonable amount  […]
